If an input is misclassified, but in principle is correctly classifiable by a perceptron, then the hyperplane plane defined by the input vector forms a new boundary constraining the cone of feasible solutions. Let us call this hyperplane *h1*. And let us call the other hyperplane boundaries of the cone of feasible solutions *h2*, *h3*, etc. Since *h1* intersects *h2*, *h3*, etc. (obviously - they form a cone), any hyperplane parallel to *h1* will also intersect them. To get to the generously feasible solutions, we just have to find the parallel hyperplane *hg* separated from *h1* by a distance equal to the magnitude of the input vector. *hg* together with *h2*, *h3*, etc. now form a sub-region within the aforementioned cone of feasible solutions, giving us the cone of generously feasible solutions. Thus, assuming finite inputs and weights, the existence of a feasible solution space implies the existence of a generously feasible solution space.

Upvotes:

The net has N units. Each unit has a weighted connection to every other unit. It was observed that such a net can only distinguish 0.15*N memories; if you try to make it hold more than that, it confuses memories and makes mistakes. A memory is made up of the binary states (bits) of the N units. Since the net can hold 0.15*N memories and each memory is N bits, the storage capacity of the net is 0.15*N*N bits. The net has N^2 weights and biases. Storing M memories requires each weight to be an integer between -M and M (from the method used to store memories in the net), meaning each weight takes log(2*M + 1) bits to store. The net has N^2 weights, so storing all of them takes N^2 * log(2*M + 1) bits.

Does anybody understand 'the storage capacity of Hopfield Nets?' I am referring to the first slide of Lecture 11b.
Upvotes:
2
The net has N units. Each unit has a weighted connection to every other unit. It was observed that such a net can only distinguish 0.15*N memories; if you try to make it hold more than that, it confuses memories and makes mistakes. A memory is made up of the binary states (bits) of the N units. Since the net can hold 0.15*N memories and each memory is N bits, the storage capacity of the net is 0.15*N*N bits. The net has N^2 weights and biases. Storing M memories requires each weight to be an integer between -M and M (from the method used to store memories in the net), meaning each weight takes log(2*M + 1) bits to store. The net has N^2 weights, so storing all of them takes N^2 * log(2*M + 1) bits.
